Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: An AI-enabled Cyber-Physical-Biological System for Cardiac Organoid Maturation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The ability to determine and control the maturation of human-induced pluripotent stem cell (hiPSC) derived tissues is critical to tissue engineering, regenerative medicine, pharmacology, and synthetic biology, which requires the interrogation and intervention of cellular activities across the three-dimensional (3D) volume of tissues and over the time course of tissue development at cellular resolution. This proposal aims to build an AI-enabled cyber-physical-biological system to monitor and control the maturation of hiPSC derived cardiomyocyte (hiPSC-CM) organoids during development. The proposed research will develop “tissue-like” nanoelectronics that can be integrated into the developing cardiac organoids, distributing the electronic sensor and actuator network throughout the entire 3D volume of the tissue and enabling tissue-level recording and control over the entire time course of development at single-cell resolution. In situ single-cell RNA sequencing will be used to integrate gene expression data with continuous physical sensing data. Machine learning and statistical models will be built for interpreting the online sensing data, and cyber-control methods will be developed for the closed-loop online control of the cardiac organoid maturation. The developed hardware and software can be applied to virtually any current biological systems, in which the change of cellular states can be reliably recorded and controlled through the electronic sensors and actuators. The success of this proposal will further merge the field of AI, nanoelectronics, and biology, bringing unlimited opportunities for access and control to biological and biomedical engineering. The multidisciplinary teamwork will represent a successful case that schools of thought from diverse fields including bioengineering, machine learning, statistics, control theory, etc. inspire and complement each other to create state-of-the-art research results in each field. The research team will also collaborate with internal and external partners to launch educational and societal activities for students from diverse backgrounds, such as providing e-seminars, workshops and new courses for undergraduate students on advanced nanoelectronics fabrication, and workshops and tours for local K-12 students to explore stem cell culture, online videos to disseminate new research in genomics, mathematical and computational modeling, integration of AI, nanoelectronics, and biology.<br/><br/>We propose to develop a seamless integration of cyber-physical systems with biological systems, enabling a closed-loop control, capable of real-time, bidirectionally, and long-term stably interrogating and intervening cellular activities across the 3D volume of tissue networks at single-cell resolution. As a demonstration, we will apply this cyber-physical-biological system to the hiPSC-CM organoids, promoting and accelerating their maturation. We will achieve our goal through the following 4 technical innovations: (A) developing technologies to integrate stretchable mesh nanoelectronics with multifunctional sensors and actuators to the cardiac organoids, enabling real-time monitoring and control of organoid development; (B) precisely registering electronic sensors during in situ single-cell RNA sequencing to determine the molecular maturation of cardiac organoids and correlate spatial gene expression profiling with sensing data at single-cell resolution; (C) developing novel machine learning models and tools to identify the statistical interference between gene expression and organoid-wide electrical and mechanical recording and also building online predictive models to real-time determine the maturation of cardiac organoids; (D) developing effective and scalable Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods to determine optimized electrical activation patterns to promote the maturation of cardiac organoids and to test its performance in patient-specific cardiac organoids.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this research is to create a seamless integration of cyber-physical systems with biological systems (CPS-Bio system), enabling closed-loop control for real-time, bidirectionally, and long-term stable interrogation and intervention of cellular activities within the three-dimensional (3D) tissue networks at a single-cell resolution. To facilitate the effectiveness of our approach, we have demonstrated the capability of thes CPS-Bio systems to promote the functional maturation of human-induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs)-derived 3D developing cardiac tissues.

We have achieved three innovations within the proposed CPS-Bio system: First, we have constructed a physical sensing and actuating system that integrates seamlessly in 3D with biological systems. Specifically, we have developed stretchable mesh nanoelectronics with tissue-like mechanical properties, implemented with various sensors and stimulators. This integration with hiPSC-derived cardiac tissues occurs naturally during tissue development. The tissue-embedded system functions as a physical sensing and actuating system, recording and controlling tissue-wide, single-cell electrical activities long-term without disrupting natural tissue development, differentiation, and maturation. We have also merged these stretchable bioelectronics with in situ RNA sequencing to form an integrated physical platform namely in situ electronics-sequencing (electro-seq). This platform stably maps and stimulates millisecond timescale cellular electrophysiology while simultaneously profiling a large number of genes at the single-cell level within 3D tissues. We have applied in situ electro-seq to 3D hiPSC-derived cardiac organoids to demonstrate its capability, which can precisely register the CM gene expression with electrophysiology at single-cell level, enabling multimodal in situ analysis. Second, we developed a multi-task deep neural network that combines joint group identification and cross-modal prediction. This network analyzes multimodal data through the integration of adversarial, clustering, and contrast learning features with coupled generative adversarial networks to enable the simultaneous multimodal data fusion and classification as well as cross-modal translation, to provide an on-the-fly accurately predict the underlying cellular molecular activities from the continuous physical sensing data. We also utilized the multimodal data to construct a pseudotime inference trajectory, which employs real-time electrical recording data to predict the functional maturation of cardiac organoids. Third, we have devised several reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms that make decisions based on continuous sensing data and subsequently provide feedback stimuli to cell groups via tissue-embedded stimulators. By integrating these three innovations, we applied the comprehensive CPS-Bio system to hiPSC-derived cardiac organoids. The results showed that organoids subjected to RL-controlled stimulation demonstrated a statistically significant enhancement in their overall electrical maturation levels and experienced a more rapid maturation process in comparison to those with fixed stimulation patterns or the unstimulated control. These results demonstrate that the application of the CPS-Biosystem can significantly enhance the maturation of organoids. We anticipate that further refinement and application of this CPS-Bio system will greatly enhance both the functional and molecular maturation processes of the cardiac organoids.

The CPS-Bio system also has broader implications for other fields. The flexible electronic device has already been utilized in various developing biosystems, including in vitro brain organoids and human stem cell-derived pancreatic islets, and in vivo brain research, going beyond the cardiac organoid system. We are further evaluating an AI agent that integrates with flexible electronics implanted in the mouse brain. By using stable electrical recording data as input, we can employ biological data to train AI agents to analyze brain dynamics.

The multimodal technology and algorithms developed in this project opened new paths in multi-omics analysis and its application across various systems. For instance, our algorithm has been successfully applied to various multimodal omics biological datasets, including, but not limited to, Patch-seq data, ATAC-seq data, and spatial transcriptomics datasets. Dissecting the trained network by interpretable learning methods has uncovered new biological insights, such as cell-type-specific, cross-modal feature-to-feature relevance from single-cell multi-modal omics biological data. The electro-seq technique has expanded to pancreatic islets and in vivo brain studies. We are confident that the CPS-Bio system, integrating machine learning, spatial biology, and flexible electronics, will profoundly impact fields ranging from developmental biology and neuroscience to brain-computer interfaces, cardiology, and regenerative medicine.

Our research findings have been widely disseminated within the research community through publications and presentations. The software developed has been open-sourced, encouraging further community development based on our work. These multidisciplinary research activities provide exceptional educational opportunities for students. The PI and Co-PIs have collaborated in mentoring undergraduate and graduate research assistants and have promoted interdisciplinary training in partnerships with other biomedical research institutes in the Boston area. The PI has incorporated the data analysis aspect of our research into both undergraduate and graduate curricula. A patent application is currently under review and a startup company, partially based on the techniques developed through this funded research, is in the planning stages.
